keyword: Information Retrieval: Computer Science-Based Breakdown
1. Information Retrieval Systems
Search Engines: Systems designed to search for information on the internet.
Web Crawlers: Programs that browse the web to index content.
Indexing: Process of creating data structures to enable fast retrieval of documents.
Digital Libraries: Collections of digital objects that can include text, visual material, audio material, and other data.
Metadata: Data that provides information about other data.
2. Query Processing
Query Formulation: The process of translating user information needs into a query.
Boolean Queries: Using logical operators (AND, OR, NOT) to combine search terms.
Vector Space Model: Representing documents and queries as vectors in a common vector space.
Query Expansion: Techniques to improve retrieval performance by expanding the original query.
Synonym Expansion: Adding synonyms to the original search terms.
Relevance Feedback: Modifying a query based on user feedback on the relevance of previously retrieved documents.
3. Ranking and Relevance
Ranking Algorithms: Methods to order search results by relevance.
Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF): A numerical statistic intended to reflect how important a word is to a document.
BM25: A probabilistic framework for scoring relevance based on term frequency and document length.
PageRank: An algorithm used by Google Search to rank web pages in their search engine results.
Relevance Feedback: Using user feedback to improve the relevance of search results.
Explicit Feedback: Direct input from users about the relevance of specific documents.
Implicit Feedback: Inferred feedback from user behavior such as click-through rates and dwell time.
4. Text Processing
Text Preprocessing: Steps to clean and prepare text data for analysis.
Tokenization: Breaking down text into individual words or terms.
Stopword Removal: Eliminating common words that do not contribute to search relevance.
Stemming and Lemmatization: Reducing words to their base or root form.
Named Entity Recognition (NER): Identifying and classifying entities in text such as names of people, organizations, and locations.
5. Evaluation Metrics
Precision: The fraction of relevant documents retrieved over the total documents retrieved.
Recall: The fraction of relevant documents retrieved over the total relevant documents available.
F-Score: The harmonic mean of precision and recall.
Mean Average Precision (MAP): The mean of the average precision scores for each query.
6. Retrieval Models
Boolean Model: A retrieval model based on set theory and Boolean algebra.
Probabilistic Model: A retrieval model based on probability theory.
BM25: A ranking function used by search engines to estimate the relevance of documents.
Vector Space Model: A retrieval model that uses a vector space representation of documents and queries.
Latent Semantic Indexing (LSI): A technique in natural language processing to analyze relationships between a set of documents and the terms they contain.
7. Specialized Retrieval
Multimedia Retrieval: Systems designed to retrieve multimedia content such as images, audio, and video.
Content-Based Image Retrieval (CBIR): Techniques to retrieve images based on visual content.
Cross-Language Information Retrieval (CLIR): Retrieving information written in different languages from the language of the query.
Mobile Information Retrieval: Techniques and systems designed for retrieving information on mobile devices.
Personalized Information Retrieval: Customizing search results based on user preferences and behavior.
8. Information Extraction
Named Entity Recognition (NER): Identifying and classifying entities in text.
Relation Extraction: Identifying and extracting relationships between entities.
Event Extraction: Identifying events and extracting relevant information about them from text.
9. Recommender Systems
Collaborative Filtering: Making automatic predictions about a user's interests by collecting preferences from many users.
User-Based Collaborative Filtering: Recommending items based on the similarity between users.
Item-Based Collaborative Filtering: Recommending items based on the similarity between items.
Content-Based Filtering: Recommending items based on the content of the items and the userâ€™s preferences.
Hybrid Recommender Systems: Combining collaborative filtering and content-based filtering methods.
10. Text Mining and Analytics
Topic Modeling: Identifying topics present in a set of documents.
Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA): A generative statistical model for topic modeling.
Sentiment Analysis: Determining the sentiment expressed in text.
Opinion Mining: Extracting subjective information from text, such as opinions and emotions.
Document Clustering: Grouping similar documents together.
k-Means Clustering: A method for partitioning a set of observations into clusters.
11. Legal and Ethical Issues
Privacy: Ensuring the protection of user data in information retrieval systems.
Data Anonymization: Techniques to ensure that individual user data cannot be traced back to the user.
Bias and Fairness: Ensuring information retrieval systems do not perpetuate biases.
Algorithmic Fairness: Ensuring algorithms treat all users fairly.
Intellectual Property: Managing the rights related to the content indexed and retrieved.
